stem: The nurse is preparing medications for Mrs. Eleanor Vance. Based on the provided information, indicate whether each medication order is safe or unsafe for this patient. Consider all data within the EHR tabs.

itemContext.sbar: S: Eleanor Vance, 78-year-old female, admitted to Medical-Surgical Unit for heart failure exacerbation. Reports increased shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. O: At 07:00, BP 160/95 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 28 breaths/min, SpO2 90% on room air. Auscultation: crackles in both lungs. 2+ lower extremity edema. Labs drawn at 07:30. A: Heart failure exacerbation, likely fluid overload. Hypokalemia noted on labs. B: Physician notified at 07:15, new orders received. Current medication orders: furosemide 40 mg IV push, digoxin 0.125 mg PO daily, potassium chloride 20 mEq PO BID, enalapril 5 mg PO daily. Vitals reassessed at 08:00: BP 155/92 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, SpO2 92% on 2L NC. Placed on droplet precautions due to possible respiratory infection.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 138 mEq/L, K: 3.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, BUN: 35 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL, Digoxin Level: 0.6 ng/mL

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
07:00: BP 160/95 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 28 breaths/min, SpO2 90% on room air.
08:00: BP 155/92 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, SpO2 92% on 2L NC.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Furosemide 40 mg IV push
Digoxin 0.125 mg PO daily
Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO BID
Enalapril 5 mg PO daily

rationale.correct: Furosemide is appropriate to reduce fluid overload, addressing elevated BP/RR. Digoxin dose is safe, given the therapeutic level. Potassium chloride addresses hypokalemia, worsened by furosemide. Enalapril is indicated for heart failure but requires BP monitoring.
rationale.incorrect: Withholding furosemide exacerbates fluid overload/respiratory distress. Digoxin level is therapeutic, so withholding is incorrect. Not administering potassium chloride worsens hypokalemia, risking arrhythmias. Enalapril is indicated for heart failure and should not be withheld without contraindications.
clinicalPearls: Assess renal function (BUN, creatinine) before nephrotoxic drugs like furosemide.
Monitor potassium with diuretics, especially with digoxin.
Titrate enalapril cautiously, especially with borderline/low BP, to avoid hypotension.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on elevated BP, overlooking hypokalemia/need for diuresis. They might miss that digoxin level is normal.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Assess all data (labs, vitals) to understand the complete clinical picture.

mnemonic.title: Potassium-Wasting Diuretics Side Effects
mnemonic.expansion: Hypokalemia, Hypotension, Hyperglycemia, Ototoxicity, Uric Acid Increase, Nausea, Electrolyte Imbalance, Skin Sensitivity to Sun
